Sarah, come on.

saw.

And I was assisted by the keyboard skills of Mrs Clarke.

Mrs Middlemint.. Theodosia? Would you accompany me?

FX: THEY GO.

Never here when she’s needed. And who’s going to remove that

20. EXT. YARD
FX: THE DOOR CLATTERS AS FLIP, MEER, SARAH AND GOREMBE EMERGE
FROM THE STABLE.
Please close the door. Clara is tired. She will soon settle.
FX: GOREMBE CLOSES THE DOOR.
Sarah, run and fetch Mrs Clarke. Or the Doctor.
No, Sarah. You do not take orders from her. Come away.
I cannot leave yet. Mrs Ramon was kind to me. You must stay with her.
People will see. I cannot stay.
Yes, you can. Keep yourself out of sight. Over there. I will bring Mrs Clarke.
FX: SHE GOES. GOREMBE MOVES AWAY, MANACLES CLINKING.
Madame, I am grateful, most grateful, for your attention. Captain Van Der Meer at your service.
FX: CRAVEN APPROACHES.
Mrs Ramon? What has happened?
(HARDLY DELIGHTED) Mr Craven. The Captain here was attacked.
Attacked? My dear sir, are you hurt?
You were not so courteous on the road, Mynheer.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 52
Forgive me. I was... ill-served by the moment. But what has happened?
I surprised someone in the stable with Lady Clara. I had left my men to guard her, but no doubt they strayed to the tavern.
And did you see the ruffian?
His face was covered. He struck me down, but he was no brawler. Oh, my Lord. Am I bleeding?
A bit. Here, use my hanky.
Thank you. (DABBING) Ugh...
We should get you back inside.
No. I cannot leave Clara tonight.
Mrs Ramon, your friend is a Doctor, is he not?
I’ve already sent for help. Thanks.
Excellent.
This place. England. Ungracious and full of mud. I knew I should never have come.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 53
21. INT. BALLROOM
FX: DISTANT GUESTS MILLING.
Mrs Clarke? I have a message from Mrs Ramon.
From Philippa? Where is she?
Outside, Madam. She asks if [you will..]
(APPROACHING) Sarah! Where have you been? You were not waiting upon your mistress!
I have a message for Mrs Clarke, Master. From Mrs Ramon.
So you run errands for others now!
Sir Geoffrey, please.
(APPROACHING) Sir, might I intervene?
No, sir. You might not.
It’s alright, Mr Naylor. Sarah, what was your message? You can tell me.
It is the Dutchman, Madam.
The Dutchman!
He has been hurt and needs attention. In the yard. That way.
Thank you, Sarah. Mr Naylor, I don’t suppose you’ve seen my companion, the Doctor?
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 54
Indeed I have. He left a moment ago with the lady.
The Doctor?
With my sister? She has gone?! While you, slovenly girl, were not in attendance!
I am sorry, Master.
Do you know where they were going?
I am not sure. Though there was much “speculation”.
Speculation! Sarah! You have neglected your mistress. I should throw you out.
Sir, no man or woman is your property.
She most certainly is, preacher! Traded and paid for. And dammit, I’ll do what I like with her! As for that Doctor... what are his intentions towards my sister?!
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 55
22. EXT. YARD
Clara is the gentlest of behemoths with the sweetest temperament. For fifteen years, she has charmed the crowned heads of Europe.
There was gossip that the King was here tonight. What nonsense.
The King? No-one told me.
(EDGY) Where’s the Doctor got to?
Perhaps he’s busy rescuing more dogs.
Why don’t you go and find him then?
And leave you unattended? That ruffian may still be around.
I can look after myself.
That I can believe. You are all fire. I shall return soon.
(LYING) Can’t wait.
FX: HE GOES.
The bleeding has stopped. (HE STANDS AWKWARDLY) Ooh... I should
look in on Clara. She may become distressed again.
Take it easy. I’1ll be right here.
FX: HE GOES.
BEAT.
FX: GOREMBE APPROACHES, MANACLES CLINKING.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page
(WHISPER) Mistress.
Gorembe? You’re on the run, aren’t you?
Yes, mistress.
Someone should look at the shackles on your legs. The Doctor would help.
I cannot stay. There are many bad people here.
What about Sarah? Is she your...?
She is my wife, yes. Please give her this.
A medallion? But.. It’s not stolen, is it?
It is important. They must not find it. They are hunting me.
They?
Please. Sarah is strong. Much stronger than I.
Okay. I’11 make sure she gets it.
FX: GATES ACROSS THE YARD CLATTER.
A GANG OF ROUGH SAILORS ENTERS.
They’re here.
(DISTANT) There he is!
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 57
Run, Gorembe.
(DISTANT) Take him!
FX: GOREMBE RUNS.
[WILDTRACK ]

YELLS IN PAIN

(OFF) We'll soon beat the gall out of you. Bring him!
(OFF) Get off me! Sarah!
FX: THEY HUSTLE GOREMBE OFF.
(APPROACHING) Philippa? What’s happening?
Connie!
Who was that?
I just stood there. I should have stopped them! Where’s the Doctor?
You may well ask.
And Sarah?
In trouble again, poor woman. She said the Dutchman was attacked. Was that the man who did it?
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 58
23. INT. THE STABLE
VAN DER MEER CONSOLES CLARA.
Clara... Liefste. (LEEF-STER [DEAREST] )
FX: CLARA SNORTS.
Yes, I know. I know. It was a shock, but I am much better.
FX: CLARA GRUNTS.
No, I’m sorry. I have no oranges left. (SIGHS) I fear we should never have come. Unreliable, ungrateful. The food is terrible and the people even more tight-fisted than the French.
FX: CLARA STUMBLES, SNORTING TO HER FEET.
Oh, steady. Stay calm, Liefste.
FX: CLARA SNORTS.
Sit down again and try to sleep, yes? We will go soon, I promise. And no more visitors.
FX: CLARA SNORTS.
No, stay calm. Please, Clara, stay calm.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL)
24. EXT. YARD
(AMAZED) A rhino?! Lady Clara?
She’s big, built like a tank.
Page 59
I’ve seen them out in the bush, of course. But here?
She and the Captain — they’re on tour... all round Europe. Like
an eighteenth century rock star and her manager.
My goodness.
Well, there’s nothing on TV is there?
But is she safely tied up? And that man they took...
attack the Captain?
No! He’s Gorembe. He’s Sarah’s husband.
did he
Oh, good grief. Alright. Just stay calm. What are we going to
tell her? She’s in trouble enough as it is.
But I should have stopped them. Where’s the Doctor? He hasn’t
really gone clubbing, has he?
FX: A CRASH FROM INSIDE THE BARN.
(INSIDE) Clara! No!
What’s that?
FX: WITH A CRASH, CLARA SMASHES THROUGH THE BARN DOOR AND
INTO THE YARD.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 60
(EMERGING) Clara!
Connie! Look out!
FX: CLARA SNORTS.
Get back!
Close the gate!
FX: CLARA MOVES OFF AGAIN, LUMBERING STRAIGHT ONTO THE STREET.
Stop her! Clara!
(HURRYING UP) By thunder, what a monster!
She’s not African. She only has one horn.
Please, Sir Geoffrey. She must be caught. Fetch her back!
We need to organise a hunting party.
A hunt?! At this hour? Now there’s a thought.
Which way did she go?
(LAUGHING) Torches, that’s what’s needed. Someone rouse the Night Watch!
No. Please. Please, no muskets or guns.
She mustn’t be hurt.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 61
She’s a danger, that’s what she is. And a trophy. Oho, imagine that head over the mantel.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 62
25. EXT. STREET
FX: DISTANT ALARM BELL CLANGING.
(HURRYING UP) Captain Hawnch?
(SLIGHTLY INEBRIATED) Mr Craven. What a pleasure. What’s all the jangle?
That wild brute the Lady Clara has broken loose and is roaming the streets.
The nosserus? (CHUCKLES) Wel11...
Round up your men, Captain.
Ooh, Mr C. We’re headed back to Bristol in the morning. Wouldn’t want to miss the tide, would we?
FX: ALARM STOPS.
I’1l make it worth your while. Or are you not up to the chase?
I’ve hunted in Africa before... but not for this sort of quarry.
Take her alive and I’1l pay you well.
Hmm. Well... How much?
Thirty pounds.
Thirty?
Forty then. Come on, Captain.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 63
Well... huh... Alright. So be it.
But alive, understand? If she’s dead, she’s not worth a penny to me. Or you.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 64
26. EXT. STREET
FX: DISTANT DOG BARKS.
Which way would the Doctor go?
I’ve no idea. We could try along the colonnade.
FX: THEY WALK.
The thing is...
What thing?
I mean... if he’s finally got himself a hot date... well, wouldn’t it be a crime to break it up?
Is “a hot date” the sort of thing the Doctor goes in for?
Dunno. Not sure what his type is.
Mrs Middlemint apparently. Who’d have thought that?
You’re not worrying, are you?
No. No, of course not. How about you?
The Doctor? No. He can look after himself.
Except...
Yes?
Well, we don’t know what her intentions towards him are either.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL)
FX: NAYLOR APPROACHES.
Ladies!
Here’s your Mr Naylor.
He’s not “mine”.
You should take shelter immediately.
Hey, vicar.
A lady?
Page 65
The streets are not safe.
If you were taking a lady out, where would you go?
You can’t be writing sermons all the time. So where would you
go?
Well... The Promenade, I suppose?
At this time of night?
The tavern?
Certainly not.
A coffee house then?
That’s possible, yes.
Right. That’s where we start. Where’s the nearest?
FX: DISTANT CRASH.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL)
[WILDTRACK ] (YELLING ROUGHLY) That way! She’s down there!
They’re getting closer.
Ladies, take cover now please!
Page

27. INT. COFFEE HOUSE
What must His Majesty have thought? If he really was there.
I hope my tricks compensated for his disappointment.
Oh, I’m sure. (AMUSED) Oh, Doctor. My dear brother would not approve.
Of us taking hot chocolate together?
Of the coffee house. I was never inside one before. It is so insalubrious.
Is he really that protective? Then I apologise for leading you astray.
Oh, no. The company is most congenial.
Even if its charms are obscured by other people’s pipe smoke.
COUGHS OSTENTATIOUSLY
But the most agreeable sight of all, Doctor, is barely obscured at all.
(AWKWARD) Ahem. What about your brother’s business? He seems to be doing well.
Geoffrey? Oh, he owns a brassworks on the outskirts of Bristol.
Really. And what do they make?
Wares for trading overseas. Pots and pans, I think. I have never visited. But in return, he brings cargoes of sugar, tobacco and coffee to England.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 68
Not necessarily from the place where he trades the brass.
I have no idea. He says the detail would worry my head. He’s so thoughtful.
But are you happy?
Happy? Oh Doctor, you remind me so much of the late Middlemint.
Your husband?
Oliver died five years ago this August... of the sleeping sickness in Africa. And ever since I have found no contentment.
I am so sorry. You must miss hima lot.

Yes. (BEAT) Oh, la. Why should I complain? My life is all diversion. Callers and gossip and suppers. And my illustrious brother cares for me well enough. So I am comfortable. But you, Doctor, you are the first ever to express any sympathy.
Life, even amongst friends, can be a lonely business. Keeping busy, that’s my philosophy.
My dearest Doctor, it is mine also.
BEAT.
And good gracious, look at the time. The night watchman we
heard must have been at least twenty minutes slow.
Is it really so late?
Yes, it is. I’d better hail you a sedan immediately.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 69
FX: CRASHES OUTSIDE.
[WILDTRACK ]
SHOUTING, HUNTING CLARA
What’s happening? There is a rumpus outside.
The usual roustabouts and roaring boys no doubt.
How exciting. Shall we see?
No, no. Home, Theodosia. If I have to escort you myself.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 70

[WILDTRACK ]

not let them harm you. Where are you?!
TO...
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 71
29. EXT. STREET (CLOSE BY
Hawnch! Have you seen her?
Not yet, sir. Along the streets by the Pump Room, that’s what I
heard. We’ll soon have her cornered.
Remember — alive. She must be alive!
TO...
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 72
30. EXT. STREET
FX: CROWD MORE DISTANT.
[WILDTRACK]
MILLING AS BEFORE
(DESPERATE) She is lost, Sir Geoffrey. Lost in your confounding streets! She must not be hurt!
She can’t stay hidden for long.
Half the city is out! It is like a fairground. Please. Make these people go home. (SHOUTS) Go home! All of you go! You will fright her the more!
Captain! You’re a man of the theatre. Perhaps you should charge them for the spectacle.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page
31. EXT. OUTSIDE THE COFFEE HOUSE
FX: SHOP DOOR CLOSES. NAYLOR APPROACHES.
Mr Naylor... any luck in the coffee house?
Apparently the Doctor and his Lady stopped briefly for hot
chocolate...
They’ve gone on somewhere else, haven’t they? Great.
Did they say where?
The owner said that the lady had to pay the bill.
Oh, Doctor.
But a house in Melville Street was named.
How far?
Only a few streets away. Towards the Pump Room.
I assume that’s where your friend Sarah will be living too.
Oh... Sarah. I have something for her.
Philippa?
(RUMMAGING) Where is it? I’ve got it here somewhere. Yes.
FX: SHE PRODUCES THE MEDALLION.
A medallion?
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 74
Gorembe asked me to give it to her. But I never got the chance.
Before they dragged him away.
The cruelty of God’s people.
He said it was important.
This object was made in Bristol, at Balsam’s Brassworks.
There are initials engraved on it too. Can I just... (SQUINTING) O.M. .. and T.B.
No idea.
But how did Sarah’s husband get it?
Dunno. He’s a runaway. He was limping... with these shackle things on his legs.
Was he off a ship?
Couldn’t say. But I doubt it. Not recently.
Come on then. There is much that Geoffrey Balsam must answer for.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 75
32. EXT. STREET
CROWD CLOSER AGAIN.
FX: HURDYGURDY PLAYING.
Hawnch! By Heaven, this is a night, is it not? It beats huntin’ otters any day!
The brute’s been seen in the back streets behind the Abbey, headed towards the river.
Then what are you waiting for? Head her off. Ten pounds to the man who drags her down.
Only ten, sir. She’s a proper levia-ga-than from what I hear.
Oh, make it twelve then. But when she’s caught, hold her still. I want to finish her off myself.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page
33. EXT. DOORSTEP
FX: NAYLOR KNOCKS LOUDLY AT THE DOOR.
Suppose there’s no-one in?
It’s the only house with lights on.
FX: MOVEMENT INSIDE.
Someone is coming.
I’m still not sure this is a good idea.
FX: DOOR OPENS.
Mrs Ramon?
(UNEASY) Sarah. I know it’s late, but is the Doctor here?
He is our friend. We need to speak to him.
Yes, Madam. He is with the mistress.
Then please tell him we are here. It is a matter of urgency.
But she said not to disturb them.
(IN AN INNER ROOM) (SHRIEK OF LAUGHTER) Oh, Doctor!
Maybe we should come back later.
Not a chance. Where are they? Through here?
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 77
FX: SHE MARCHES IN.
Please Madam, no!
Sorry. We have to see him.
(INSIDE)
ANOTHER SHRIEK OF LAUGHTER
FX: INSIDE, URCLEES THE PUG STARTS BARKING.
(INSIDE) Oh, be quiet, Urclees!
Right then.
FX: CONSTANCE OPENS THE DOOR.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 78
34. INT. DRAWING ROOM [CONTINUOUS]
And I’1l1 swap you Mrs Plug the Plumber’s Wife for Mr Bun the Baker!
FX: URCLEES YAPPING.
Oh, be quiet, silly boy.
Doctor!
Philippa? Mrs Clarke? What are you doing here?
Sorry. Erm.. We didn’t mean to intrude.
Intrude? Mrs Middlemint and I were only playing a hand of cards.
And I am winning! Imagine that! The dear Doctor is so amusing!
Yeah... hilarious.
(TOTALLY INNOCENT) Why? Whatever did you imagine?
BEAT.
More guests. I love a houseful. Sarah, fetch some tea at once.
I’ll give you a hand.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 79
35. EXT. STREET
HAWNCH AND HIS MEN ARE IN HIDING.
FX: CLARA COMES TRAMPING OUT OF THE DISTANCE.
(MUTTER) Here she comes, lads. The nosserus is coming through. Ropes ready.
FX: CLARA STOMPS CLOSER.
Wait... wait...
BUT CAPTAIN VAN DER MEER EMERGES FURTHER DOWN THE STREET.
(DISTANT) Clara! Over here!
FX: CLARA STOPS.
That tulip-bothering Dutchman!
(DISTANT) Clara! Here, to me!
FX: CLARA SNORTS.
Now! Rope her now!
(DISTANT) No!
FX: THE ROPES FLY. CLARA SNORTS AND RUNS. A STACK OF WOODEN
CRASHES DOWN.
Gah! Missed her!
(DISTANT) You fools! Clara! Come back! (MOVING AWAY) Clara! Clara!
Get after her, lads. Don’t lose her again!
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 80
36. INT. KITCHEN
FX: SARAH LOADS TEACUPS ON A TRAY.
(DISTRESSED) No, mistress. This is my job.
I’m trying to talk to you.
They will hurt Gorembe...
I had to tell you. I’m sorry.
They have taken him away. And that will be an end of him. Because they are our masters.
FX: SHE MOVES CUPS AGAIN.
Not all. Some of us want to help.
You know nothing. You do not even notice.
Sarah... Gorembe asked me to give you this. This medallion.
Ah...
FX: SARAH TAKES THE MEDALLION.
I don’t know what it means.
He gave you this?
Yes. For you. Is the inscription important?
It is from him.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 81
FX: NAYLOR ENTERS.
Mrs Ramon?
Not now.
If I can help, I will. (BEAT) Sarah, where did they take your husband? Is it back to the Brassworks? (BEAT) How many others are forced to work there?
Too many.
Are they slave workers? Is that how it works? Because it’s run by Sir Geoffrey.
Take this, Sarah. It is a prayer book. Come to my meetings if you can. With God’s help, we shall do all we can to stop this abomination.
But sir... I cannot read.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 82
37. INT. DRAWING ROOM
You thought that I could capture a runaway rhinoceros?!
It’s dangerous. People could be hurt.
Well, that’s very flattering. I can be dangerous too, you know.
And the Captain is very upset.
Aren’t I allowed even one evening off? Mrs Middlemint and I were simply...
I’m sorry.
No, Doctor. You must go. You are needed.
Theodosia, please.
I have relished every moment. And we can always do this again.
(LYING) Well... yes. Yes, of course.
Thank you. Urclees and I can hardly wait.
Right then. I’m ready. What do we know about the fabled Lady Clara?
FX: DOOR OPENS.
(ENTERING) (FLATLY) She tours Europe.
Philippa? Are you okay?
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 83
I’m fine. Clara’s very gentle... usually. Sorry, not much help.
She loves oranges.
Really?
I read it in a pamphlet.
Ah, the joys of advance publicity.
I only noticed because my brother has a whole Orangery full.
Of oranges? Gosh.
At the back. Overlooking the parterre.
Mrs M, you are an unqualified genius! Thank you!
(ECSTATIC) Oh... And I thank you, ‘Mr Drudge the Doctor’, from the bottom of my fluttering heart.
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 84
38. EXT. STREET
FX: CLARA SNORTS AT A DISTANCE.
(MUTTER) Oho... there she is, Hawnch. Nowhere to run. Ripe for the kill. What a beauty.
Ready, lads? On my mark.
One moment. You recall what I told you, Captain? Take her alive.
Mr Craven? You’re rising above your station, sir. Hawnch works for me. And I say, the brute is my trophy.
But the Captain and I have reached an agreement. Did he not say? The rhinoceros is mine.
Hawnch? Are you lining both your pockets?
I’m not party to the disputes of gentlemen, sir. I merely follow orders. So does the nosserus live or die?
(DISTANT) (CALLING) Lady Clara?
What the deuce?
(D) Here. Over here.
It’s that Doctor. What’s he doing?
And Mrs Ramon is with him.
This is our sport. How dare he interfere? She’1ll be the very death of them!
DW #231: THE BEHEMOTH by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 85
40. EXT. ALONG THE STREET
THE DOCTOR ENTICING CLARA, PLACING ORANGES ALONG THE STREET.
Is she taking the oranges?
FX: CLARA SNAFFLES.
She certainly is.
Strategically placed. Not too close together. But enough to
draw her on.
